39110101.review:
What can I say. I love RTS games, and this fits into the catagory of what I love IN a RTS game. It has amazing diversity, the AI keeps you on your toes, custom maps, mods, and the multiplayer is very easy to set up. This is a gem of a game, im excited to see what it will hold in the future.

Pros: 
+Cheap
+Many maps + custom maps makes good replay value
+Multiplayer is very easy to use, and setting up a game with friends is quick
+Unit diversity is ever expanding, from many types of aircraft to mech
+Amazing modding potential due to the more simplistic style
+Very small file size compared to most games now
+No pay to play, or dlc, or any payed bullshit in general
+Extremely optimized, I have NEVER gotten any lag spikes or lag in general. Even with
100s upon 100s of units moving and firing at once.

Cons:
-Honestly none. I can't find anything I do not like about this game. I guess the only thing
that could fit into this category is that there could be steam workshop support, but thats likely 
to come anyways.

Things I'd like to see: 
-Some sort of vehicle that can traverse lava. It would be a great strategic advantage on a lava map to 
have some sort of vehicle in the lava, and hovervehicles cannot travel over it.
-A way to give money to allies
-Helicoptor buffs. I was able to beat two helicopters with one scout. They are VERY weak.
-Maybe a vehicle able to deliver nukes while mobile? It would likely be very expensive and not able to hold 
many nukes, but it'd be a nice touch.
-Strange, but maybe an underground unit? Maybe you can drill underground and make room to build underground of some sort idk, but it'd be cool to sneak under enemy lines and then drill a hole one their side and flood them with troops. Although this would need a balance like a ground radar to see under the ground, and maybe bombs and fights above ground can destroy the underground areas.
-A type of bomb similar to a nuke but instead it makes like a temporary repair zone that can help and heal your troops. This would be good for large assault groups, and It would provide for some interesting tactics.
-A wall system. If you could acually build walls of some sort maybe in different tiers to defend against oncoming attacks that would be awesome. And maybe some sort of mortar tower that can fire around artillary range, but it can go over walls an terrain.
-An In-game map editor.
-Weather. This would provide for really cool ambience, and if there was alot of wind it could make troops travel slower in the direction of the wind. Could provide a minor advantage.

Overall, 9.3/10. Its hard to find issues with this. I would recommend this to anyone who wants an RTS game.

38356184.review: Great game and lots of content

38050309.review:
This is one hell of a RTS wargame - especially for the price (4.99).  I've been gaming for 30 years now and this is one of my favorite RTS games.  I wasn't paid to write this review, and I didn't get the game for free.  I played this game on a tablet for several months and when I saw it available on Steam I bought it and added it to my library.  You will be hard pressed to spend $5 any better than you could by purchasing this game.  It's straightforward: build extractors to mine money and then build units and mechs as fast as you can.  Defend your bases and go after the enemy.  There are air, land, and sea units, as well as some units that are amphibious.  The graphics are not cutting edge but the game-play mechanics are rock solid and it has high replay value.  When I get that ol' RTS itch, this is my go to fix right now.  I would recommend this game to every single person on Steam.  I purchased a copy of this for my son and we just got done with a multiplayer game where we teamed up against a computer opponent.  It was fun coordinating our attacks and then upgrading to build better units to counter the computer's newer units.     
     Rusted Warfare absolutely has that classic RTS feel.  The production buildings and economy are simple enough that you focus mostly on the battles and your strategy - not micromanaging a ton of other things that keep you from fighting.  The battles can get pretty intense and involve over a 100 units at a time - even more if you're doing multiplayer.  You do need to keep your armies balanced though so that you can deal with a multitude of enemy units with different capabilities.  Overall it is a totally refreshing game that provides a challenge in a classic RTS format.  This game ought to be trending right now - it just needs a little more exposure and word-of-mouth recommendations.  I'm doing my part with his review.  Pick this game up you won't be disappointed.

37159182.review:
i dont write many reviews, but i felt the need to write one here, i dont have allot of time in this game but love it so far, i am a huge RTS fan all the way back to the original C&C games and Dune... this has the same feel of the classics, it has some challenge without being too hard, i jumped right into it.. no tutorial needed for someone with any RTS experience, access to all units in the first mission as long as you upgrade your buildings, my greatest joy in this game was holding off many attacks until i was able to build 5 experimental tanks and 2 heavy battleships and lighter units, being able to just roll through the enemy bases was amazing, those heavy ships are expensive and takes time to build, so you feel like you earned that power and not just a cheat, cant beat the price for what you have

pros
classic graphics
fun gameplay
many units all with a purpose
can easily run on a potato

cons
suffers from what all RTS games suffer, if you turtle long enough you can build an army that is impossible to stop, but thats not a con against this game

all around good game, great for that classic simple RTS itch, would love to see a story campagn at some point

36703430.review:
It is nice to see a new RTS in 2017 as I feel the genre is pretty much dead but one of my favorites. I notice a lot of people saying "is a lot like C&C" but to be honest the game is so close to an old RTS call "Total Annihilation" I almost thought it was a clone. This is not a bad thing, as TA was the best RTS of it's time in my opinion. You will notice it using many of the same map designs, units, resource mining and defenses from TA.

Completely worth the money and easily my favorite game for this year that I have purchased. Highly recommend.

35832063.developer_response:
Do you have a carrier grade NAT (not just a normal router NAT?) if so drectly hosting your own game will be quite tricky or impossible. You can still host game's though steam matching making by inviting your friends and it will work though steam's proxy servers. Otherwise you can also setup games though dedicated servers. And joining multiplayer should still work fine.

35517011.developer_response:
A big reason for that is the game gets pirated a lot in china, much more than paying users. And a lot of the chinese players seem to have unstable connections.

The game is built in a way that other players with high ping shouldn't effect you at all, only your own ping should really matter.

And if you are having trouble starting a match, if you join the auto dedicated servers they will always force start a minute after 4 players join.

Also happy to hear what kind of work you think the game needs.

35410409.review:
The game features a number of single-player modes: scripted missions, balanced skirmishes, and endless survival matches. In addition, maps can be edited in the game, and cross-platform multiplayer is available allowing players on Windows, Linux, and Android systems to play together. The interface is very basic and lacks some features, like infinite queues (or even queueing up things in advance without paying for them) and auto-explore. Rusted Warfare only features one resource (cash), extracted from specific locations on the map (or produced at a lesser rate anywhere). Cash is used to build factories (land, air, sea, and mech), defensive turrets, repair structures, and shields. Cash is also used to upgrade structures to higher tiers so they can produce more advanced units. The AI is a decent competitor. Rusted Warfare doesn’t offer anything innovative to the genre, instead producing some combination of Red Alert and Supreme Commander; shallow economics and simple unit countering (along with extremely tedious end-game clean-up) limit potential strategies. That said, the price is very reasonable and cross-platform multiplayer is a nice feature. But overall, the limitations of Rusted Warfare hold it back just enough from being a satisfying take on the classic real-time strategy game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1RS9JpRJSzc

35382108.review: For $5 I would say this game is definitely worth it. If you played Supreme Commander or Total Annihilation you will most likely enjoy this game. Along with normal skirmishes and online the game also has some missions, challeneges, and endless survival modes you can play.

It is what it claims to be -- a RTS, following in the footsteps of Total Annihilation and the C&C/RA series.

And it does a remarkably good job of this.  Amazingly good, really.

35313717.review: Yes, this really is what it says it is. A RTS game inspired by the classics of this genre. In this case obviously Total Annihilation and to a degree some otheres to my judgement (notably Command and Conquer: Red Alert). Rusted Warfare therefore is a classic RTS with modern netcode. It is fun and smooth enough. It's a 5 dollar/Euro strategy game following the legacy of old RTS classics. Nothing more, but more importantly nothing less. It is well done and updated frequently. I do recommend trying this. Given its price tage it's certainly worth it. Well done, Corroding Games. Well done.

The in-game editor is awesome, its basically god mode. it's everything I wanted from Total Annihilation as a kid.

Sound effects could use a bit of work though, I miss units and buildings making noises when I command them. That's my only beef with this game though, so GG 'corroding games', please don't abandon it, build your name on this title. keep polishing it like you're pitching it to Nintendo and you'll have life-long fans... Like me.

And I'd happily buy a sequel for much more than I bought this.

34031590.review:
For a game with such price I'd say it is decent, the graphic and sound are acceptable to me personally and AI is performing well, units are distinctive to recognize(but there are issues with them which I'll bring up later). I was quite enjoyed playing with such large battle so smoothly after the failure of Supreme Commander 2 and the scam of Planetary Annihilation.

However it has some serious balance issues(ie. submarine vs missile ship) while lack in some fundamental UI structure that any RTS should have, for example when selecting units the game selects everything including engineers and even all buildings, also there's no indication on what types and how many units are selected neither. 
For a game with such scale, there's no user-friendly unit marker visible on screen when zoom out to show what kind of unit is there, so I have to either select them all or zoom in again to see what is there, combine with the lack of selection indication, it really creates frustration during my brief playtime.
There's no build queue for factories when fund is low, so I have to go back to factories(I know there are shortcuts, but hey, just trying to make a point:) ) and click to build again whenever I have enough funds to pump out more units. This might be nitpicky to others, but we are talking about TA/SPC/PA level of combat scale with hundreds of units being pumped out every minute, a queue system can greatly improve the combat flow and ease up the micro-managing part so players can focus more on the combat side and greatness of this game.

Lastly the localization, it's good to have more languages for broader appeals, it's extremely business hurting to have languages translated poorly using google or some sort. I can't speak for other languages, but Chinese in game is full of BS and not much of it make any sense.

Unfortunately despite how much I enjoyed this game I need to request a refund due to the reasons above, but I will thumb the game up in the review as it really achieved many that many other games failed to delivered. I'll keep eyes on this game and hope for its success in the near future and buy it back again.

Desperto en mi, de nuevo esa sensación que experimente cuando jugue por primera vez a un RTS, este juego es dinámico, sencillo, divertido, graficamente muy resultón (me recuerda a los gráficos de "Creeper World 3", parecen simples pero esconden un gran encanto), gran variedad de unidades, con efectos bastante buenos, explosiones, humo, agua, en fin, muy decente en general,....ah y super barato. No llevo demasiado jugado cuando he escrito este análisis ,pero creo que voy a jugar bastante. 33713342.review:
As I write this the game has only been out for about a week but its already clear there is a great game here.  This is in the vein of traditional RTS games that I played in my youth in fact I would say this feels very much like Total Annihilation at the moment. 

As it stands right now there is one 'resource' to farm which gives you funds to build ships/tanks/aircraft.  This means that the resource squares make for obvious pinch points which require defending and also are obvious areas to attack.  The game concentrates on the fun element of building the armies and have big all out battles which is great.  The AI seems pretty decent as well which is very important part of a single player game and personally I have only so far played the single player game which has been fun.  Its well balanced with the AI and thats an important part of a game like this as it makes for a fun mechanic.  This review therefore covers only the single player element and not the multiplayer game which I have not yet tried.  

Overall this is a very reasonable price for a fun old school RTS game and I can certainly recommend it. 

For those people who play on Linux I can state that this played as smooth as butter on my Debian based gaming machine.    Seems to have great support for the Linux kernel which is nice.

33708001.review:
As an RTS (and I've played 90% of them) It's probably one of the most shallow base building games I've come across. Once you get down an extractor or 2 to give you an initial jump start, you can hammer out money fabricators to your hearts content without any penalty other than a high initial cost outlay. There's no power requirements to any building, because there is no power or resource management whatsoever.. so long as you can churn out enough cash generation, it's just a matter of hammering out as many units as you can.

Cost is the main issue you have to manage and that's it. So long as you can protect, upgrade and go nuts building your fabricators, you're laughing all the way to victory. As I mentioned it's just about making sure you can afford high cost, higher tier units up-front. In my eyes this is one of the game's biggest flaws.

Another flaw is map design.. other than water ways to go around, maps are extremely featureless. There are no rocks, trees, hills etc... everything is flat with different colours. There are a few maps here and there with additional terrain height. But there's not nearly enough, and their design is still woefully basic.

The tech tree is a very limited as well. you build the prerequisite factory, and if you want more powerful units, you click the structure then press "Upgrade" for a small fee, after a short time period you have access to all tier 2 units. If you want experimental, you build the factory for that. You don't need higher tier builders to build higher tier buildings. The basic builder will also build your superweapon.. It once again falls down to high cash requirements.

The only real choice really you get in upgrading are the turrets. Levelling those up allows you to choose a turret type.

That said I don't wish to take away from the game any more than that. As an RTS, the combat is incredibly solid, and the usual Rock Paper Scissors mechanics are on point with any other RTS on the market. As you would expect from AAA when it comes to Air , Land, Sea warfare, you'll get the combination layers required to make the breakthroughs you need.

As a single player game, there's plenty of content here. But milage will vary on that because of the shallowness of the building mechanics. To get the most out of the game with the AI, you do have to crank it up to higher difficulties, this will make the game interesting enough to give it legs as the AI will be smarter than your typical RTS. It'll still do it's cheaty thing by having additional bonuses. But it does have elements of actual intelligence here and there, that when you see them, you'll be quite surprised at it.. It doesn't just build to a certain quota of units and then chuck them at you, This is actually a big pro.

The game does shine in the Multiplayer though as the shallow mechanics make more sense here. Facing off against human opposition is as good as any other game. It's your usual yet very solid arms race in creating the best Military Industrial Complex. I would say that if you want this game, this is what you play it for, with fighting higher difficulty AI 2nd...

You get what you pay for really. So you can't expect much at this price point. But you will get your money's worth for a basic RTS that does the core elements of RTS right, has a decent AI at higher levels and provides a decent multiplayer experience. Fot those reasons I will give the game a thumbs up. 

But If you're looking for an RTS with depth, plenty of upgrade options and a deep tech tree with nuances to work around, you won't find it here, and you'll be better off sticking with the games that inspired it. Alternatively if you must go for an indie TA/Sup-Com Clone with the depth you desire there's Machines At War 3, which is also on Steam.

33672495.review:
Do you miss old school RTS? Do you like base building and prefer macromanagement over micromanagement? Then this game is for you!

[b]Rusted Warfare[/b] is an awesome RTS for everyone who enjoyed classics like Total Annihilation and Command & Conquer. It has 37 skirmish maps, sandbox mode, endless survival mode with three maps, seven challenges, eight missions and the possibility to create your own map for any game mode. You’ll get a lot bang for your buck for this price.

What I like the most is the AI – it’s pretty good even in the easier settings. If you’re a single player like me, there’s a lot of fun to be had with six difficulties to choose, and if you enjoy multiplayer matches, it’s even better, since there’s cross platform play between Windows, Mac, Linux and Android.  

Also, it’s worth mentioning that the game is really well optimized and it has multi-core support, allowing for thousands of units on the screen without lagging. The dev is passionate about his game, always improving it and answering your questions.

All in all, [b]Rusted Warfare[/b] is a really great buy and it will become even better with time. If you have any interest in RTS game, this is a no-brainer.

33555508.review:
A fun cross platform RTS inspired by old classics like Total Annihilation. 

TL;DR: Captures the old school feel really well, excels in multiplayer team battles.

The game itself is fairly simple: there's one resource type, which you typically mine at the start of the game, and then build more expensive buildings in later game to produce it. There's a single "race" but you have a fairly varied selection of units (air/sea/land units plus upgrades for each type, experimental mega-units that excel in different aspects, plus of course, nukes). The varied selection of units I feel brings some good strategy to the game - e.g. you might build a big land force, but your opponent might see it coming and counters you with air units etc.

While single player works I didn't spend too much time there, and feel the game shines in Multiplayer. You have varied start options (e.g. start with experimental units, or start with just a builder, start with additional resources etc and plenty of maps to choose from. 

Playing with teams is great as you can have teammates playing the early game and pumping out cheap units to keep your opponents on the defence while you build up a mega army for the late game (which can be a hell of a lot of fun :)).

In terms of updates: I played this on android a long while ago and it seems to have come a long way, with more units, more maps, more start options etc. It's early days but looking at the developer responses in greenlight and how far the game has come makes me think the updates will keep coming :)

Also note for linux gamers: game functions perfectly for me on ArchLinux (using steam with runtime).

Disclaimer: I received the game for free, before steam release and did some beta testing for the dev.

33551711.review: Great and simple RTS. Plays smoothly and isn't overly complicated. Could be considered a "coffee break" RTS since matches last on average half an hour. At $5, this game is an absolute steal and I can see myself putting many hours into it.

33551329.review:
Rusted Warfare seems like a solid little RTS. The pricepoint is nice and the games typically don't last for more than a half hour or so. I've played two multiplayer matches so far and it is fun with friends. There is an endless wave survival for singleplayer that I hope eventually gets co-op suppot.

It's not the most in-depth RTS, but is fun for a quick game with friends.

33547779.review: Excellent , j'attendais la version steam depuis des lustres, car sur ma tablette tactile du 18ème siècle, le jeu ne tournais pas a plus de 15 fps , donc je ne vous dis pas en multi, bref... Même avec un pc pourri, vous pouvez le faire tourner aissément. Pour ceux qui ne connaissent pas rusted warfare, c'est des batailles géniales de navires, tanks et avions au caractéristiques différents, ainsi qu'une vingtaine de bâtiments militaires , certains pour entrainer vos troupes, les défences, ect... Et pour finir en beauté, le multijoueur ! Car les 4 contre 4 ca promet (d'ailleur en fin de partie, il y a tellement d'éléments  à l'écran que pour un mobile, c'est chaux) voilà une des raisons pourquoi j'attendais sa sortie steam. Vous avez toujours révez d'être plus riche que Donald Trump en fin de partie grâce a vos 1615111445 fabricators construit pour financer des tanks expérimentaux énormes qui vont sur l'eau et nique des mères ou bien construire des lanceurs de missiles nucléaires ultra violents ? Si c'est le cas, ce jeu est fait pour vous, pour la modique somme de 4€, il en vaux LARGEMENT le coût.

33547663.review: bought on android and pc and im glad it came to pc also i like the new troops and the crossplay i would like to see it on ios one day but there are so many maps troops, turrets and the multyplayer is very fun with friends i hope this gets more people playing and behind your game good job and i hope you guys also like this game too have a good day.

33547118.review:
I've had this game a while on my android, and often thought about how it would be great to play on a computer, because sometimes the screen was to small to enjoy the game fully. But now its on steam, so thats just great.
Becaue of that, I'll also probably now be able to create a few hundred units without lagging the game.

From the mobile version, the music seems to have gotten better, with more variety, and the menus have been reskinned, and the computer's keyboard allows for more shortcuts.

On the actual game, it's probably one of the best RTS games I've ever played, with pleasing graphics, easy controls, and a variety of great units, ranging from your ordinary tank, to the spectacular experimental spider.
The AI is pretty good, but I feel like it could be improved in the way of setting up defenses, and launching more effective attacks. They also seem to never use the experimental units. But I suppose that's what multiplayer is for.

The sandbox mode is really fun to mess around in as well, additional features that could make that more fun might be if you could adjust game constants (build time multiplier, damage multiplier, etc)

The level designs are pretty good, something that might be nice for some levels would be high mountains that no units can go through/over, or maybe caves that aircraft can't go in.

10/10 best cross platform RTS

39595023.review:
I have to say that I am totally amazed about this cool little RTS game in Rusted Warfare. First off I'm a sucker for old school games with the kinda throwback graphics, and this game here pulls it off well. I like how there's some simplicity in the game, but at the same it's a beast based on what missions or mods you're playing. When it comes to RTS games, my first were C&C and RIse of Nations and it amazes me when I play a game like this or any other RTS game how far the genres has come. Anyways, I bought this game 3days ago of this review after being notified that it does support Mac in which I assumed it didn't, and have to say that this game is freaking awesome on my MacBook Air for on the go.



Thanks a bunch for this hella cool game and hope to see it on iOS being that it's got some great reviews on Android.

39532239.review:
Honestly, this is a great little game. There's nothing groundbreaking here but it has all the elements needed to make a great classic RTS. Plus, it's cheaper than the cost of admission to the theatre. So even if I only get 2 hours of solid entertainment (Likely I'll get far more) then it's still money well spent. 

>>Update>> Per the developer's request, I reviewed the info he provided and agree with his explanation. I wrongly assumed that a song I heard in a game produced by a larger firm belonged to that firm when instead, it was open source material. My apologies to the developer and my thanks for the prompt and concise response. 

>>There is one tiny little thing though. It's not so much a complaint as it is a concern. I am almost positive I have heard at least one of the background songs in another game. I can't quite put my finger on it but I think it's either Lego Starwars or Lego Batman. Either way, it's highly unlikely that the developers paid for the rights to it or scored their own ochestra. It doesn't bode well that a nascent studio would blatanty commit copyright infringement. My guess is that they won't be around long. Either because they get sued out of existence or because they're just not very smart..
39532239.developer_response:
I'm very careful with copyright. You're liking talking about The planets - Mars a soundtrack from 1914, it's available here: https://opengameart.org/content/holst-the-planets-suite and https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gustav_Holst_-_the_planets,_op._32_-_i._mars,_the_bringer_of_war.ogg and many more places as public domain.

Other sound tracks are have an open source like copyright license, and I did pay to have some of short ochestras tracks created, it's a cheaper than you would expect. But isn't a real ochestra.

If you are happy with my explanation could you update your review as to not unnecessary scare others or turn away streamers.
